author: richselby
title: Lovely Little House
review:
You won't find this set amongst the City or Creator range. Instead it's in the novelty section of the Lego store, where the desk calendars, keyrings and drinking mugs accumulate. Despite looking like a house at first glance, it's supposed to be a container for pens, pencils etc.

Box/Instructions

The cheerful yellow box is larger than the other sets in this part of the store, e.g. seasonal sets. 

Parts

Nothing fancy, but a good selection of 1 x n bricks in blue and yellow, and a fair few red roof slopes. With 174 parts, this set offers plenty of bricks for your bucks. 

Minifigures

?Like the house itself, the figures are rather old-school. A gentleman with an interest in the construction trade, and a lady prepared to swoon in admiration at such a gent. 

The build

Clever techniques? Novel use of parts? Nope. The build is as straightforward as you would imagine. My 5 year old boy was able to follow the instructions and build with me.

The apex of the house sits on tiles, so it can come off to allow quick access to the attic room. There's just about room for a hat-less minifig in there.  

The completed model

Quite charming. Maybe it's the proportions, or perhaps the simplicity, or possibly the basic colour scheme.  Or is it because it reminds me of  Lego models from the early eighties when the world was a much simpler place? Whatever the reason, something about this little house appealed to everyone in the family. 

There's one problem.  Where the balcony should be, there's a hole. Which is fine if you intend to use the house as a pencil pot  -  as per the official name of the set and indeed the illustration on the box. However, if you just want a basic Lego house, you'll probably want to carry out some home improvements. My son and I enjoyed adding a balcony, some railings, some water in the yellow planter on the left, and windows round the back of the house. You will need nothing beyond the kind of bricks you get in a basic starter box to do this. 

Overall opinion

A charming vintage-style house. Great value for money. Easy to improve and adapt. Although this is at the opposite end of the spectrum to the Parisian Restaurant, it's still got a lot going for it.
